Award.AwardTitle: Heat Kernels and Geometries in Discrete and Continuous Settings
Award.AbstractNarration:
Models of human activities often involve randomness. Randomness is used to understand DNA, image restoration and recognition, communication and social networks, and the behavior of financial markets. It is an important tool for efficient computations and for scientific simulations. In all these applications, the behavior of the model's random process is constrained by the combinatorial or geometric structure underlying the system under study. This project is concerned with the fundamental properties of such stochastic processes and how they relate to the global geometric structure of their environment, be it discrete or continuous. The project provides training opportunities for graduate students.

The project focuses on random processes that are defined by a related geometric or algebraic structure. The global behaviors of these processes are determined by this global structure. In some cases, these behaviors are useful to obtain information on the underlying space. This research lies at the interface between analysis, geometry, and probability, with the notion of group playing a key part. Partial differential equations and potential theory, i.e., the study of harmonic functions and solutions of the heat equation, are also at the center of many of these considerations. Brownian motion on a Riemannian manifold and random walks on Cayley graphs of finitely generated groups provide key examples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted fro this project produce  novel understanding of the properties of the solutions of basic partial differential equations (e.g., the heat diffusion equation) and associated stochastic processes (e.g., Brownian motion, random walk) evolving in a geometric environment affecting their behavior.  Concrete examples include the diffusion of heat in  metallic pieces of various forms, shapes and metal composition, shuffling cards and other mixing processes that aim to approximate an ideal desired probability distribution, and Gambler’s Ruin problems involving many players engaged in a fair game. Many further examples involve complex mathematical concepts (e.g., manifolds and groups). The project produced new understanding of  basic properties such as sharp two-sided bounds on the distribution of heat at a given time in terms of the geometry of the underlying object. 

 

These results concern stochastic processes and partial differential equations that are widely used by the scientific community to understand real world problems via modeling, algorithms,  and simulations. Both the results and the techniques developed to obtain these results are relevant in producing models and simulations schemes, in analyzing these models and the results of simulations, and understanding how they relate to the real world (e.g., biological processes, DNA analysis, financial markets analysis).

 

The PI taught graduate courses providing an introduction to the relevant areas of research and to the technical tools necessary for making significant contributions in these research directions. Undergraduate students, graduate students and early career mathematicians worked with the PI  on this project. They were trained in understanding and using cutting-edge techniques to obtain novel results and develop their own research agenda.  The findings of the project are published in international research journals and disseminated through participation to international conferences.
